body:
@josevalim @lucasmazza pull request up at #2937.

My bug fix/improvement has test coverage, and I also backported tests for the existing functionality.

At some point I may backport tests for yield functionality across all controllers, but I'll handle that separately.

Thanks for the quick feedback on this original ticket.
Closing this in favour of the pull request, thanks!

Sorry to bother with this, but on the update action, how can we know the value of `resource_updated`? In that case, `.persisted?` does not help nor does `.valid?`â€“ is there another method I can easily swap in that I'm just not thinking about here? Would it make sense to also pass in the `resource_updated` in the yield block? I.e. `yield resource, resource_updated if block_given?`

Thanks @josevalimâ€“ that does solve part of the issue. The reason I wanted to pass in the variable `resource_updated`, is that I'm using the yield block to run another set of updates with an external API. In the case that that update fails, I want to set `resource_updated` to `false` so that it goes to the failed branch of the update action. 

Though `resource.errors.empty?` allows me to determine whether the resource was successfully updated in the line just above, I can't change the course of action in the `yield` block (other than manually setting a `redirect_to path and return` commandâ€“ but this skips out of the other methods you all have written with this controller action).

Essentially, it'd be something like so:

```
super do |resource, resource_updated|
  if need_to_update_with_external_api
    resource_updated = resource_updated && update_with_external_api(resource)
    if resource_updated
      # run some custom actions here, set a flash message perhaps
      # enter into the `resource_updated = true` branch when finished with the yield block
    else
      # set some other flash message here
      # enter into the `resource_updated = false` branch when finished with the yield block
    end
  end
end
```

This may be way too specific for you all to worry about, but by simply passing along the `resource_updated` to that block, I think I can use the same behavior without needing to completely customize/overwrite the controller.

@krnjn Good use case.

@josevalim I realize this is a much, much larger idea, but for a long time I've wished that devise would decouple all this logic from the controllers and into a service layer so the specific functionality of creating accounts, updating accounts, initiating password resets, etc. would be isolated from controllers. This would make it much easier for people to slice/dice/combine the functionality needed and allow access to it from things like Rake tasks, service objects, custom controllers, etc. Do you have any thoughts on that?

I'd much rather see the `Devise::RegistrationsController#create` be simplified to look like:

```
def create
  result = Device::RegistrationService.create(params)
  if result.success?
    ...
  else
    ...
   end
end
```

Immediate use-cases that come to mind:
- For managing users from Rake tasks
- For managing users from backend admin areas like ActiveAdmin
- For use in other service objects that coordinate user management with other components
- For use in API controllers
